skill.name: reasoning-dialectical
skill.description: Synthesize competing positions through structured thesis-antithesis-synthesis process. Use when stakeholders disagree, trade-offs exist, or multiple valid perspectives need integration. Produces integrated positions with acknowledged trade-offs.
skill.summary: Synthesize competing positions through structured thesis-antithesis-synthesis process. Use when stakeholders disagree or trade-offs need balancing.
skill.author: BellaBe

security_audit.summary: All 41 static findings are false positives. The skill is a prompt-based dialectical reasoning tool with no executable code. Backtick detections are markdown code formatting, not Ruby/shell execution. Hash values and technical terms were misidentified as cryptographic/C2 patterns.

content.user_title: Synthesize opposing viewpoints with dialectical reasoning
content.value_statement: Teams often struggle to reconcile conflicting stakeholder positions. This skill applies structured dialectical analysis to identify valid points in each argument, surface essential trade-offs, and generate synthesis positions that move discussions forward productively.
actual_capabilities: Identify and articulate the core thesis position in any debate or decision
Surface the opposing antithesis with equal rigor and fairness
Analyze tension points to reveal underlying assumptions and trade-offs
Generate synthesis positions that preserve valid elements from both sides
Document acknowledged trade-offs in any integrated solution
Guide teams from conflict toward productive resolution
limitations: Does not access external data or documents outside the conversation context
Cannot make decisions on behalf of users or commit to outcomes
Effectiveness depends on the quality of input perspectives provided
Should be used as a thinking aid, not a substitute for human judgment

use_cases.title: Resolve product strategy conflicts
use_cases.description: Product teams facing competing feature priorities can use dialectical analysis to understand why each proposal has merit, identify shared goals, and synthesize a roadmap that addresses core needs.

use_cases.title: Balance technical debt vs feature velocity
use_cases.description: Engineering leaders can apply structured reasoning to evaluate arguments for shipping fast versus building sustainably, finding integration points that serve both short-term and long-term health.

use_cases.title: Facilitate stakeholder alignment workshops
use_cases.description: Facilitators can guide cross-functional teams through structured dialectical exercises to move from entrenched positions toward collaborative solutions with clear trade-off documentation.

prompt_templates.title: Quick synthesis check
prompt_templates.prompt:
Apply dialectical reasoning to this situation:

Thesis position: [Describe what one side advocates for and why]

Antithesis position: [Describe the opposing view and its reasoning]

Identify: 1) What each side gets right, 2) Where the core tension lies, 3) A synthesis position that preserves valid elements from both, 4) Remaining trade-offs to acknowledge.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need a quick structured analysis of two competing options

prompt_templates.title: Multi-stakeholder alignment
prompt_templates.prompt:
Conduct a dialectical analysis for [topic or decision]:

Position A (represented by [group]): [their argument in their own terms]

Position B (represented by [group]): [their argument in their own terms]

[Add more positions if relevant]

For each position, identify the underlying concern being protected. Then synthesize: What shared values emerge? What integration is possible? What must be explicitly traded?
prompt_templates.scenario: When three or more stakeholder groups have competing priorities

prompt_templates.title: Personal decision dialectic
prompt_templates.prompt:
Help me think through [decision] using dialectical reasoning:

Option X: [Why this path is compelling]

Option Y: [Why the alternative is compelling]

[Option Z if relevant]

Apply thesis-antithesis-synthesis: What is the core value driving each option? Where do they fundamentally conflict? Is there a third path that honors more values? If not, what trade-off is most acceptable and why?
prompt_templates.scenario: When making personal or professional decisions with competing priorities

prompt_templates.title: Evaluate existing synthesis
prompt_templates.prompt:
I have a proposed solution for [issue]: [Describe proposed synthesis]

The original tension was between:
Thesis: [Original thesis position]
Antithesis: [Original antithesis position]

Evaluate this synthesis:
1) Does it preserve the strongest elements of both positions?
2) What trade-offs does it make?
3) What might advocates of each original position object to?
4) Is there a stronger synthesis possible?
prompt_templates.scenario: When reviewing and improving an existing proposed solution

output_examples.input:
Thesis: We should prioritize the new mobile app because our users are increasingly mobile-first and competitors have better mobile experiences.

Antithesis: We should focus on the web platform because it serves power users better, requires less maintenance than native mobile, and our analytics show desktop conversion is higher.
output_examples.output:
### Analysis

**What Each Side Gets Right:**
- Thesis correctly identifies mobile usage trends and competitive pressure
- Antithesis correctly notes desktop's higher conversion and lower maintenance burden

**Core Tension:**
The tension is between market opportunity (capturing mobile users) and operational efficiency (serving high-value desktop users). Both are valid but point toward different resource allocations.

**Synthesis:**
Prioritize a progressive web app (PWA) that delivers mobile-friendly experiences while leveraging existing web infrastructure. This serves mobile users without the full native app maintenance cost.

**Remaining Trade-offs:**
- PWAs cannot fully replicate native app capabilities (offline, push notifications, app store presence)
- Desktop users may see reduced investment as focus shifts to mobile experience

output_examples.input:
Thesis: We should implement feature-flag-driven development to enable faster iteration and reduced release risk.

Antithesis: We should maintain traditional trunk-based development with comprehensive testing because feature flags introduce complexity and technical debt.
output_examples.output:
### Analysis

**What Each Side Gets Right:**
- Thesis correctly identifies that feature flags enable safer, faster releases
- Antithesis correctly warns about complexity accumulation from flags left in code

**Core Tension:**
The tension is between release velocity and code simplicity. Both approaches aim to reduce risk but from different angles.

**Synthesis:**
Adopt feature flags with a strict retirement policy (all flags must be removed within 2 sprints). Use flags only for genuine experiments and gradual rollouts, not as a substitute for feature completion.

**Remaining Trade-offs:**
- Some upfront investment needed in flag management tooling
- Requires discipline from the entire team to maintain flag hygiene

best_practices: Present both positions in their strongest form before synthesizing. Steel-man the opposition rather than attacking a weak version.
Explicitly name the trade-offs in any synthesis. Clarity about what is being given up builds trust and prevents later surprises.
Use dialectical analysis as a thinking aid before making decisions, not as a substitute for stakeholder input or expert judgment.
anti_patterns: Using synthesis as a way to avoid making hard decisions. Sometimes one position is genuinely stronger and should win.
Skipping the antithesis phase. Presenting a weak opposing view and then easily refuting it produces poor synthesis.
Treating the synthesis as a compromise average. Good synthesis should be greater than the sum of its parts.

faq.question: When should I use this skill versus making a unilateral decision?
faq.answer: Use dialectical reasoning when multiple stakeholders have invested perspectives, when the trade-offs are genuinely uncertain, or when buy-in matters for execution. Make unilateral decisions when you have clear authority, when speed is critical, or when the decision falls clearly within your expertise.

faq.question: How many positions should I include in a dialectical analysis?
faq.answer: Start with two (thesis/antithesis) for clarity. Add a third position when there is a genuinely distinct perspective that does not reduce to the other two. More than three positions can become unwieldy but may be useful for complex multi-stakeholder situations.

faq.question: What makes a good synthesis?
faq.answer: A good synthesis preserves the strongest elements of competing positions while transcending their limitations. It should be more than a compromise (splitting the difference) and more than a preference for one side. Look for integration that neither position would have discovered alone.

faq.question: What if the positions are genuinely incompatible?
faq.answer: Document the incompatibility clearly. Sometimes synthesis means explicitly choosing one path with full acknowledgment of what is lost. The skill helps clarify when positions are irreconcilable versus when integration is possible.

faq.question: Can this skill help with personal decision-making?
faq.answer: Yes. Apply the same framework to personal choices: articulate what draws you to each option, surface the underlying values, and look for integration or explicit trade-offs. This works well for career decisions, investment choices, or lifestyle trade-offs.

faq.question: How does this differ from pros and cons lists?
faq.answer: Dialectical reasoning goes deeper than pros and cons. It asks about underlying values, examines where positions conflict at the level of principles, and seeks synthesis that may reveal options neither list would suggest. Pros and cons are useful input to the process but not the process itself.
